content.body: Does anyone understand the problem that might be solved by poetry markup, as being discussed on public-html?
I just can't figure out what user agents could do with the markup that would make it more useful than just using the existing, more general purpose elements.
Lachy: I get the impression from LML that Hoffman is concerned with poetry being read aloud differently.

"Prose is in general text with no specific requirements for the presentation of rhythmic or rhymed content. On the contrary the presentation should not pronounce accidental rhythmic or rhymed fragments."
Lachy: Not significant, but I think you just missed http://krijnhoetmer.nl/irc-logs/whatwg/20100121#l-83
fwiw, in case anyone was wondering, macbooks aren't waterproof.
Lachy: see also http://markmail.org/message/6pxz74sm3zcs4gn3
Hixie: This sounds like wisdom gleaned from bitter experience :(
yeah.
Lachy: So: 1) read stuff aloud differently and 2) expose the structure of the poetry itself as visible data.
Are they water-resistant?
what's the threshold?
i.e. how much water would they have to resist for the answer to be yes?
I don't know, but I assume the terms have some conventional meanings.
I think "water-resistant" means it will be okay if you take it out in the rain, "waterproof" means it will be okay if you drop it in the bathtub.
Roughly.
ah
well
where do you think half a glass of water straight into the keyboard fits in this spectrum?
maybe laptops should have depth ratings on them, like watches do
"rated up to -1cm below water level"
where such depth ratings do not correspond with the actual water depth they are capable of handling.
like, e.g. a watch rated at "30m" corresponds to roughly splash resistant from, e.g. a tap while washing hands.
hah
Hixie, so I think you're supposed to take out the battery and let it dry out?
Apparently it will often be okay if you give it a few days to fully dry.
Hixie, you have a terminal. Can't you just use the date command for that?
the clock in my irssi window gives me CET time :-)
but yes, i could have used terminal too
i just happened to already have google open
is CET the time zone I'm in?
is it 02:39 where you are?
I'm guessing Central European Time
yes
then yes
Hixie, maybe you missed this earlier...
<Lachy> Hixie, re: using HTTP URLs for Microdata itemtype, does it have to be a URL at all? http://lists.whatwg.org/pipermail/whatwg-whatwg.org/2010-January/024770.html

<Lachy> The problem I have with using URLs for this, and for namespaces in general, is that formats will most likely out-last the organisation that created them and assigned the namespace or itemtype URL
what should we use instead? people didn't like the reverse-dns identifiers
and urls are what rdf uses already
users didn't have any problems dealing with urls in the studies, fwiw
I know that, and realise we're stuck with URLs, at least for RDF conversion.
I just don't like the idea of tying widely used metadata formats to one particular organisation.
*shrug*

and one of the problems that has occured with namespaces is that there's no widely used convention for how the URLs should be structured, so we've ended up with a wide range of confusing, non-memorable URLs
which often contain effectively meaningless stuff like the years in the older W3C namespaces
e.g. compare http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml, http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom (note the unexpected capital A), http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace
so I would prefer that we could come up with a simpler, predictable format for itemtype, which identify the format, without identifying the organisation that happened to define it
this is not a battle i want to engage in, but if you can find a solution that i can adopt without having to spend effort defending, i'll happily do so
I also assume that using a centralised registry won't go down well either, since one of the claimed benefits I've heard for using URLs, is that it piggy backs on top of the existing DNS registry

long term i think we need to support URLs anyway, given the volume of vocabularies already using them, and if we have to support _two_ mechanisms, that may be worse than URLs, however good the alternative mechanism
which may be an argument for not bothering
(it was the argument against reverse-dns -- it just wasn't enough of a gain to be worth it)
hmm, ok. That does suck that we have to continue to suffer from the mistakes of RDF and namespaces :-(
just like we have to suffer from SVG's design mistakes
btw, is there any plan to switch the itemtypes from using n.whatwg.org URLs to W3C URLs, or is the intention just to keep those permanently, regardless of whatever eventually happens with microdata?
and just like people in the future will have to deal with ours
e.g. the storage mutex
i don't intend to change anything
ok
of course if the w3c can provide a better URL (-> shorter, memorable) before that one gains usage, then i don't see why we wouldn't use it
it's going to be nice when spammers inevitably take over whatwg.org and start serving ads or even malicious content from those URLs
i wish i could renew domains for more than 1 year at a time
i'd just renew it for 100 years if i could
that depends which provider you register it through
dreamhost
I thought the maximum permitted by the .com registry was about 10 years
that's already pretty miserly
Maybe DNS won't exist in 100 years, then you wasted your money.
but I once saw one registrar use a loophole to allow 100 year registrations, where they would register it for 10 and promise to keep renewing it automatically
AryehGregor: it's ok, by then the money would have been worthless anyway :-P
http://www.w3.org/mid/201001201816.14025.Dr.O.Hoffmann⊙gd
"Already XHTML2 was considered to be too progressive"
i really don't think that's the criticism i would level at XHTML2
Maybe "too progressive" means "trying to make too much progress".
XHTML2 was one of the slowest moving specs the W3C has ever worked on, so that doesn't seem like a valid criticism either
I said trying, not succeeding.
As in, it tried to improve HTML as much as possible, even regardless of backward compatibility.

Are there any examples of a basic rails app which syncs offline/online data using HTML5?
hmm
Hixie: ayt?
Hixie: I guess you are since you just said something
hey
I have a hopefully brief question relating to a WebKit bug
someone submitted a patch that would cache the actual NodeList objects returned by getElementsByTagName, getElementsByTagNameNS, getElementsByName, and getElementsByClassName
so if called on the same node with the same parameter twice, they would return the same value
DOM Level 3 Core seems to explicitly forbid this for gEBTN and gEBTNNS
but for the two specified in HTML5, it does not say one way or the other
here is the bug: https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=33696
my comment links the relevant spec sections: https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=33696#c17

my question to you is whether HTML5's silence on whether these methods return a new object is meant to intentionally diverge from DOM Core and allow caching, or if it's just an oversight and is actually supposed to match DOM Core
the latter
ok
can you file a bug for that?
I will
thanks
I think it would be better if DOM 3 Core and HTML5 both allowed caching, but it certainly seems bad for them to differ
so probably the right thing to do is fix it in DOM Core first
i would rather scripts always get reliably a new object
so that they don't start getting non-interoperable behaviour if they're messing with properties on these objects
either it should always return the same object or never, imho
that is indeed somewhat safer to always return a new object
it seems like it'd be relatively easy to implement wrappers that make it seem like they're new objects while being mostly the same object internally
the only reason I was enthused about the caching is that I think setting custom properties on NodeLists is kinda rare, and the performance win seems really big
that is in fact what we do currently
what's most of the win from?
is creating JS objects that expensive?
I believe most of the win is from not allocating the JS-level wrapper, but it's not my patch and I did not do profiling so I can't say for sure
ah
maybe you can do copy-on-write magic or something
that's not really practical to do with JS objects
they can easily share all their innards but be different wrappers, and we do that already (essentially)
but you can't have two pointers to the same JS-level wrapper turn different later
so there's no way to avoid doing an allocation on every call with the current requirements
seems like you should be able to add one level of indirection -- one pointer and one bit, in fact -- but i guess the code complexity would be disproportionate
and i guess the cost could be prohibitive
relative to the win

it's really the fixed overhead of allocating the JS wrapper that I believe is the expensive part, so adding a level of indirection would not help, since the indirect part would have to be allocated as a JS value itself
to work with the GC
ah, yeah
surely your JS wrappers are all fixed-size and can be arena allocated really cheaply
seems odd that that would be the expensive bit
allocating the actual NodeList, sure
GC allocation ain't cheap
allocating the C++-level NodeList might be a big part of the cost too, and in theory we can have distinct wrappers for the same C++-level NodeList
I think our caching right now is of an object that's shared by multiple C++ NodeLists
I can suggest trying that to the contributor and see if returning the same actual JS-level NodeLists still looks like a big win after
filed http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=8792
with the caveat that i am talking out of my nether regions, it seems like getting GC structures to allocate fast would be a good win in general
but i expect you have experts who are better positioned to work out this kind of thing :0)
:-) even
poured water on his macbook pro yesterday and has been relegated to an X41
running Windows
what a life
Hixie: I am sure JSC and V8 have both put a good bit of work into tuning our respective GC allocators
there are some fundamental limits
yeah
in the case of this test it's not just the allocation, but the fact that you are creating lots of garbage
and every garbage JSNodeList needs to have a finalizer
makes sense
that will strain any GC algorithm I know of
anyway I r-'d the patch for now
I am finding that a lot more WebKit contributors are submitting stuff lately that I have to r- because it directly violates a spec, without apparent compatibility need (or similarly good reason)
I am not sure what to do about this
also I am far from the only reviewer so I wonder how much of that sorta thing is slipping through
not that it's your problem
yeah i dunno what the solution is
what other kind of stuff has there been?
one that I specifically recall is someone submitting a patch to implement HTML5 footer that tried to enforce the content model in the parser
i.e. it would actually reparent on an attempt to nest <footer> elements
oh yeah, i saw that one
that seems like a pretty fundamental failure to read the spec
some of the feedback on the mailing lists has been like that too
standards are complex
and it can take a while to get up to speed on some of the basic concepts

othermaciej, from what I can tell, it seems that Minefield does return the same object from subsequent getElementsByTagName calls. (Opera and WebKit don't)

http://software.hixie.ch/utilities/js/live-dom-viewer/?%3C!DOCTYPE%20html%3E%0A%3Cp%3Etest%3C%2Fp%3E%0A%3Cscript%3E%0Avar%20a%20%3D%20document.getElementsByTagName%28%22p%22%29%3B%0Aa.foo%20%3D%20%22FAIL%22%0Avar%20b%20%3D%20document.getElementsByTagName%28%22p%22%29%3B%0Aw%28%22Same%20object%3A%20%22%20%2B%20%28a%20%3D%3D%3D%20b%29%29%3B%0Aw%28%22foo%20property%3A%20%22%20%2B%20b.foo%29%3B%0A%3C%2Fscript%3E%0A
Lachy: ORLY
Lachy: that's a direct violation of DOM Level 3 Core if true
I wonder if it is intentional
Lachy: Minefield only, or also release Firefox?
Lachy: doesn't happen in Firefox 3.5.2 for me
Lachy: cannot reproduce
Lachy: in latest Mnefield on Mac
oh, I gess the w function is not doing anything
Lachy: seems to be true in Firefox 3.5.2 as well
Lachy: not sure whether to file a Firefox bug or r+ the WebKit patch to do the same now...
I am not sure how to find out if this kind of thing is intentional
wish there were someone here to ask
Boris would most likely know
othermaciej: I did some hg mining but I didn't find anything obviously intentional in the post-3.5 time frame
hsivonen: the change already exists in 3.5.2, my initial testing was mitsaken
othermaciej: http://mxr.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/source/content/base/src/nsContentList.cpp#221
othermaciej: there's a cache whose existence predates the migration to mercurial
othermaciej: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=140758
if Mozilla is already doing this for a long time and doesn't have resulting problems, then it's likely not a compat problem to allow it
I don't know about the absence or presence of problems
hsivonen: so it seems intentional and longstanding to return the same NodeList, but there doesn't seem to mention of intentionally violating the DOM spec
othermaciej, the w() function just outputs the value to the log below. It says "Same object: true" for me in Minefield, but false in Opera and WebKit
Lachy: I see the same (after changing to document.write) and Firefox 3.5.2 also has the Minefield behavior
hsivonen also found that this Firefox behavior dates back to 2002
wasn't the w() function working for you?
I might not have looked in the right place
it's in the log at the very bottom of the page, below the rendered view of the page
indeed I did not - since the log was scrolled off the bottom of my window
othermaciej, why are we going to do a new CfC for publishing Microdata?
Lachy: the new CfC will be for HTML5, Microdata, 2D Context, and HTML+RDFa to all get first or new Working Drafts
Lachy: reasons for a new CfC are threefold:
(a) some of the objections from the first one will be addressed by Hixie's changes
(b) the HTML5 proposed for publication originally will be materially changed by the further splitting of 2D Context
(c) may as well just have one CfC for everything we want to publish
you know, it strikes me that i have no way to describe a string as having to match the HTML or XML syntax
this seems like a substantial oversight
really? How do you state that requirement for innerHTML?
there are no conformance criteria for what hte value passed to innerHTML should be
ok
i guess for this body="" or whatever we end up calling it, i can add a new subsection to the syntax section that describes a document with the doctype made optional
and then i can make the <title> section say that it can be omitted for these types of documents
i'm leaning towards calling the attribute doc="" or srcdoc="" again, btw, since body="" doesn't really work if it's a full doc (especially in xml)
you could call it content=""
that's confusingly similar to <meta content>, especially with microdata
it would also screw over RDFa
which I'd rather not do
ok
how would it screw over RDFa? Do they use a content attribute?
yeah, iirc
I don't mind if you screw over RDFa. I'm ignoring their spec entirely
inlinesrc="..."

in w3c terms that's positively timely
contrast with us (the htmlwg), we're at this point something like a year or two behind schedule

I guess this is basically because everything published as a FPWD must become a REC or a NOTE

so pagehide is supposed to fire in all iframes of a pages that is being navigated away from, right?
are there some exceptions to this?

"User agents may wait for a suitable break in the user's interaction before queuing the task; for example, a user agent could wait for the user to have not hit a key for 100ms, so as to only fire the event when the user pauses, instead of continuously for each keystroke."
So I guess this means we need to use onkeypress or onkeyup instead of oninput?
If we really want to have it be per key.
I guess there's no event that fires after the input has happened, so that it will reliably fire once each keystroke and event.target.value will be the current value?
Why would you want such a thing?
What do you expect it to do with input methods where you use multiple keystrokes to insert a single character?
Just give the current value after whatever the user just entered.  Really I want an event whenever the contents of the form field change, with the new value of the field.
For using <datalist>.
Why is 100ms latency unacceptable?
I want to dispatch the new contents to my backend to ask for suggestions.
Because the result has to be thrown out if the form value is no longer the same when the suggestion returns, and there already may be a significant round-trip delay.

You'd have to implement some kind of buffering yourself anyway, because you don't want to send a request to the backend after every keystroke if the user's typing really really fast and has a dialup connection
tries to figure out if MW already buffers
It looks like we usually wait 250 ms, except if the user hits the down arrow.
We use keyup, keydown, keypress, blur, and focus, but of course we also use a <div> positioning hack right now to generate the results.
Probably we don't need to hook blur and focus with datalist.
Using datalists via JS is really ugly, by the way.

Given that pages will have to implement some kind of buffering if some browsers don't buffer themselves, it seems silly for the spec to say "may" - it should require buffering for all browsers or none

I'd really prefer just input.suggest = ['Foo', 'Bar'] instead of creating a datalist element, making up an id, giving it the id, setting the input's list attribute, and looping through the result list to add <option> children.
(maybe)
Anyway, yeah, "may" is a pain.
Author feedback from attempting to use the element is a good thing to have :-)
